div.p:
Thank you my dear Miss Robinson for your kind
letter & I am much obliged to you & Lady Robinson for
your kind wish of seeing me at Cranford; if ever I
should go into that part of England, which I fear
is highly improbable I should certainly not neglect
to pay my respects to her Ladyship or to renew my
acquaintance in person with her agreeable daugh-
-ter daughter - I am going on though not with so much
alacrity with the work I have began, for the first
volume has been gone some time and we are afraid
as we have heard no news of it, that some accident
has befallen it - Alas it would be a woeful mischanc
enough to discourage a poor scribbler at her first
setting out - however I shall begin the third
vo-
-lume volume next week - how we are talking of
Books pray have you read a new work of
Madme..-
-de Genlis Madame de Genlis
the same lady who wrote Le theatre d'
Edu-
-cation Education
which you used to be so fond of, the title
of it is Lettres sur L'Education ? if you have what
do you think of it? If you have not I think it very well
worth reading if you should have an opportunity -
Les Annales de la Vertu 3 vols are advertized I see in the
last papers by the same Author - I have not yet read
this last work - She is a very indefatigable & a very
constant Writer for all her her works are on the same
subject - this is the least that can be said of her - the
rest you will judge of yourself - I was very much pleas-
-ed pleased with a book I met with lately it is written by the
celebrated Abbe Raynal the title of it is Anecdotes
historiques 2 vols it contains a history of some very
important Revolutions, of Sweden, under
Gusta-
-vus
Vasa, the reign of Charles the fifth, the conspira-
-cy conspiracy of Fiesque in Genoa, the divorce between Henry
the Eighth & Catherine when the protestant religion
was established in England this is the most unin
teresting part of the Work - the revolution under
Gustavus Vasa & the Conspiracies of Fiesque are
the best part of it I think - I should think a very good
play might be founded onthe conspiracy of Fiesque:
the Count
is a fine, strongly marked, enter
-prizing enterprizing , ambitious, character, his wife his brothers & two of
his friends would also form good theatrical cha-
-racters characters - the plot is simple & the action would
not exceed the usual limited time of a day & a night
If it falls in your way, I should be glad to know your
opinion of it - You ask me if my Italian is flown
over to Eng & Italy with Mr. Amici? - I shall have lei-
sure leisure to read & study Italian next summer but at
present I shall be very glad if I preserve what I know
already - which in truth is very little - - -

You have mentioned in several letters that you
were going to Balls - I have an odd question to ask you
Are you happier at a Ball than anywhere else?
You will laugh & say to be sure I am; & perhaps you
will ask me why I make such an uncommon in-
-quiry inquiry ? I will tell you why - because I am inclined
to believe
what I have not need of my company
that it is the preparations, the Musick, the dress
the praise & the bustle which constitute the charms of a Ball - there-
-fore therefore will you my dear Miss Robinson favor me with
an exact and clear answer to this question - but I must
beg you to deduct the Degrees ofpleasure which arise from all
the things I have mentioned; if afterwards you find that
you still feel pleasure which arises from none
of those causes I wish you would find out what
it arises from & let me know -. our tastes do not in
these respects, I believe, agree but I see the obvious
cause for their disagreeing - you have a very agree-
-able agreeable person, agreeable manner & many external
accomplishments which I want ; you are active
nimble & dance well, I am awkward & dance very
ill, it is not therefore in the least surprizing that you
should be happy in a ball room where you are prais-
-ed praised & at least equal to others in those qualifications
which shine most in publick Assemblies or that I on
the contrary with every personaldisadvantage
& others which arise from awkwardness &
Mauvaise nouse should feel myself much less at my ease
in company , than amongst friends who set little
comparitivevalue on such Qualifications - >compari
-tive
comparative value I said for because I want them myself I would
not depreciate them in others; I know their value; for I know
the want of them; & the pain arising from that want is cer-
-tainly certainly the most exact measure of their worth - You know
I used to be laughed at for my definitions & told that I
should sit up by a lamp like the philosophers of old; but
however I am not to be ridiculed out of a good thing
a girl of fifteen & a philosopher when joined sound ridi
-culous ridiculous to be sure: but if we attend to the thing & not to them
to despise what it either does not or will not understand
I think you did not say you had seen Miss Burney yourself
I wish you had for I wish very much to know what kind of
woman she is - Whenever you write to Wimpole St . remem
-ber me to all my friends: you said Miss Van would probably be
gone by the time you return how comes that?- -

I beg you will give my love to all the young ladies I know
with whom you correspond - & tell them that I have not
forgotten them - I believe in some of your musick-
-books you have a song said to be written by Lord Little
-ton Littleton
on the death of his wife, if it would not be giving
you a great deal of trouble to copy it I should ask the
favor of you to send it me for I think the poetry is re-
-markably remarkably elegant & I have never been able to meet
with it since I left Mrs. Devis's - the name of the
lady is Lucy - Adieu my dear Miss Robinson
div.closer:
I am your's affectionately
Maria Edgeworth
